# packages/adapter-rust/vendor/codelldb/linux-arm64/lldb/lib/python3.12/site-packages/pip/_vendor/requests/compat.py
@source-hash: 328f5ff7166979fa
@generated: 2026-02-09T18:00:48Z

## Purpose
Legacy compatibility shim for the requests library, originally designed to handle Python 2/3 compatibility. Now serves as a centralized import location for standard library modules and type definitions for backward compatibility.

## Key Components

### Character Detection
- `_resolve_char_detection()` (L17-20): Stub function that returns None, indicating character detection library support has been removed
- `chardet` (L23): Global variable set to None, maintaining API compatibility

### Python Version Detection
- `is_py2` (L33): Boolean flag for Python 2.x detection (always False in modern usage)
- `is_py3` (L36): Boolean flag for Python 3.x detection (always True in modern usage)
- `_ver` (L30): Reference to `sys.version_info` for version checking

### Standard Library Re-exports
- JSON handling (L40-41): Imports `json` module and `JSONDecodeError`
- Collections (L44-45): Re-exports `OrderedDict`, `Callable`, `Mapping`, `MutableMapping`
- HTTP utilities (L46-48): Re-exports `cookiejar`, `Morsel`, `StringIO`
- URL parsing (L53-64): Comprehensive re-export of `urllib.parse` functions
- HTTP request utilities (L65-71): Re-exports proxy and parsing functions from `urllib.request`

### Type Aliases
- `builtin_str`, `str`, `bytes` (L73-75): Type references for string handling
- `basestring` (L76): Tuple of string types for isinstance checks
- `numeric_types` (L77): Tuple of numeric types (int, float)
- `integer_types` (L78): Tuple containing only int type

## Dependencies
- `sys`: For version detection
- `json`: For JSON handling
- `collections`/`collections.abc`: For data structure types
- `http`: For cookie and HTTP utilities
- `io`: For string I/O
- `urllib.parse`/`urllib.request`: For URL and request utilities

## Architectural Notes
This module serves as a compatibility layer, centralizing imports and providing consistent APIs. The character detection functionality appears to have been deliberately disabled. All Python 2 compatibility code is now vestigial but maintained for API stability.
